name: Dionysius of Corinth
subtitle: Unified Martyrdom of Peter and Paul
details: Writing in the late second century, Dionysius of Corinth, a bishop, testifies to the martyrdom of Peter and Paul, describing their deaths as a unified witness of the early church. In a fragment preserved by Eusebius, Dionysius states that both Peter and Paul "suffered martyrdom at the same time."
whyItMatters: It confirms an early tradition of apostolic martyrdom, showing belief in the sacrificial deaths of Peter and Paul by the mid-second century.
It links the two leading apostles in a shared testimony of faith, highlighting ecclesial unity in their witness.
The tradition is cited by Eusebius, a major historian, which adds historical weight to it.

source.title: Dionysius of Corinth, fragment cited in Ecclesiastical History, Book 2, Chapter 25, Section 8 (trans. Arthur C. McGiffert via CCEL)
